Abstract: This paper explores the intricate relationship between vision, action, consciousness, and attention, proposing a novel framework that rethinks traditional paradigms. By synthesizing findings from cognitive neuroscience, psychology, and philosophy, we argue that vision and action are not merely sequential processes but are deeply intertwined, influencing each other in a dynamic loop. Consciousness and attention play pivotal roles in this interaction, modulating the flow of information between sensory inputs and motor outputs. Our analysis suggests that understanding the mechanisms underlying these processes requires a holistic approach, considering both the neural substrates and the phenomenological experiences. This study aims to contribute to the ongoing discourse by offering a comprehensive model that bridges the gap between empirical research and theoretical perspectives, paving the way for future investigations in this interdisciplinary field.
